excerpt: Carcassonne, a hilltop town in southern France’s Languedoc area, is famous for its medieval citadel, La Cité, with numerous watchtowers and double-walled fortifications. The first walls were built in Gallo-Roman times, with major additions made in the 13th and 14th centuries. Château Comtal, a 12th-century castle within the Cité, offers archaeological exhibits and a tour of the inner ramparts.
detail_description: Carcassonne, located in the Languedoc area of southern France, is renowned for its medieval citadel, La Cité. The citadel features a double-walled fortification and numerous watchtowers dating back to Gallo-Roman times with later additions in the 13th and 14th centuries. Within La Cité lies Château Comtal, a 12th-century castle offering archaeological exhibits and inner rampart tours.
name: Carcassonne

detail_description: The Canal du Midi is a 240-kilometer waterway that stretches from Toulouse to the Etang de Thau, featuring 63 locks and 350 engineering structures. Travelers can enjoy tranquil journeys by cycling along the old towpaths or leisurely cruising on a barge, taking in the picturesque French landscapes of lush fields and charming villages.
name: Canal du Midi

excerpt: Large, restored 12th-century hilltop castle, with a museum in this renowned, medieval walled city.
detail_description: Château Comtal is a large 12th-century hilltop castle located in the medieval walled city of Carcassonne. It was the seat of the Trencavel family, Viscounts of Carcassonne, before being annexed by France in the 13th century. The castle now houses a museum where visitors can delve into the city's fascinating history.
name: Château Comtal

detail_description: When visiting Carcassonne, don't miss out on exploring the charming medieval district of La Bastide Saint-Louis. Often overshadowed by the old city, this area is a hidden gem just a short walk from the ramparts. Located south of the river Aude, it offers a glimpse into daily life with its French bars, cafes, shops, and restaurants. Take a stroll across Pont Vieux and immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere of this historical neighborhood.
name: La Bastide Saint-Louis

excerpt: Scenic lake lined with walking paths & parks offering zip lines, water slides, beaches & dining.
detail_description: Lac de la Cavayère is a picturesque lake just a short drive or bus ride from the city. The area offers 40 hectares of water and pine woodland, with three small beaches, walking paths, and various activities for visitors. From pedalos and mini-golf to an inflatable playground on the lake, there are plenty of options for families. Motorized boats are not allowed, creating a peaceful atmosphere for gentle walks in the forested hills and family picnics.
name: Lac de la Cavayère

detail_description: Pont Vieux, also known as the Old Bridge, is a historic 210-meter-long structure dating back to 1359. It replaced an older feudal bridge and served as the sole connection between two parts of the city for centuries. Now strictly for pedestrians, it is considered one of the most romantic spots in Carcassonne. The bridge offers breathtaking views of landmarks such as the Barbie Palace and Sainte-Cecile Cathedral.
name: Pont Vieux
address: Rue du Pont Vieux, 11000 Carcassonne, France

excerpt: A vibrant rose window adorns the facade of this elegant, Gothic-style 12th-century church.
detail_description: Basilique Saint Nazaire is a stunning 12th-century church in Carcassonne, featuring a mix of Romanesque and Gothic architecture. The facade boasts a vibrant rose window, while the interior showcases exquisite stained glass and impressive stone carvings. The city of Carcassonne also includes other attractions like Le Musee International du Dessin Anime and Le Pont Vieux, offering breathtaking views of the illuminated citadel at night.
name: Basilique Saint Nazaire
address: La Cité, Pl. Saint-Nazaire, 11000 Carcassonne, France

excerpt: Small fine-arts museum specializing in paintings & ceramics from the 17th century to the present.
detail_description: Located just behind the famous cathedral, Musée des Beaux-Arts de Carcassonne is a small yet impressive fine arts museum housed in an elegant 18th-century building that was once the bishop's palace. Established in 1836, this museum offers a diverse collection of artworks spanning from the 17th century to the present day.
name: Musée des Beaux-Arts de Carcassonne

detail_description: Carcassonne, located in the Occitanie region of southern France, is a historic city famous for its medieval fortress, La Cite. This UNESCO World Heritage Site boasts well-preserved medieval architecture, including high walls and narrow cobbled streets that date back to the Roman Empire. The Bastide area within the city is a highlight, surrounded by boulevards constructed on former moats from the 18th and 19th centuries.
name: Carcassonne

detail_description: Portail des Jacobins is the only remaining city gate of the four that once surrounded the new town. It provides a link between the old and new parts of Carcassonne, with its high vaulted arches dating back to the 14th century. The area offers a pleasant space for leisurely strolls and is steeped in historical significance, making it an ideal spot for exploring local history.
name: Portail des Jacobins

detail_description: Carcassonne Airport is a small but efficient regional airport with only a handful of daily Ryanair flights. The passport control and security process are smooth, and there are minimal queues for check-in and boarding. The airport offers a shuttle bus service to the town center, making it convenient for travelers. While the facilities are limited with just one shop selling snacks and sandwiches, as well as vending machines, the airport maintains clean restrooms and ample seating.
name: Carcassonne Airport

detail_description: The Carcassonne Festival, held annually in July, is a cultural extravaganza set in the old town. The event features a diverse range of artistic and musical performances catering to various tastes, including opera, pop music, jazz, and metal. The highlight of the festival takes place at the Jean Deschamps theater, an impressive amphitheater within the medieval city walls that can accommodate up to 5000 spectators.
name: Carcassonne Festival

detail_description: Embark on an enchanting journey from Toulouse or Montpellier into the captivating region of Languedoc, where history comes alive. Discover the stunning medieval fortresses like Carcassonne, with its impressive architecture and rich stories. Stroll through charming ancient streets that echo tales of yesteryear, and indulge in the delightful flavors of Pic Saint Loup wines that perfectly capture the essence of this beautiful area.
name: Languedoc-

detail_description: A great way to end a beautiful day in Carcassonne is by strolling through the narrow streets of La Cité Médiévale, perched on a hill and surrounded by ramparts. The medieval architecture can be leisurely admired while enjoying the numerous bars and restaurants available. This hill has been fortified over the centuries by various civilizations, and after falling into disrepair, it was restored by Viollet-le-Duc.
name: La Cité Médiévale

excerpt: Small, simple museum featuring various objects & photographs relating to medieval torture.
detail_description: The Museum of the Inquisition offers a glimpse into the dark history of medieval torture and the role of the Catholic inquisition, particularly focusing on the Cathars in the 13th century. The museum features various objects, photographs, and reproductions that showcase inventive methods and tools used for torture during that time. It is not recommended for young children due to its graphic nature, but older kids and adults interested in delving into this darker chapter of history may find it intriguing.
name: Museum of the Inquisition

excerpt: Citadel surrounded by double walls 3km in length, dotted by 52 towers, founded in Gallo-Roman times.
detail_description: Cité de Carcassonne is a historic citadel with a rich history dating back to Gallo-Roman times. This UNESCO World Heritage site is renowned for its impressive double outer walls stretching over 3 kilometers and adorned with 52 defensive towers. Visitors can enjoy breathtaking views of the surrounding landscapes from the inner ramparts.
name: Cité de Carcassonne
address: 1 Rue Viollet le Duc, 11000 Carcassonne, France

detail_description: Château et remparts de la cité de Carcassonne is a must-visit in Carcassonne, France. The main attraction is the 12th-century chateau, which was originally built as the feudal castle of the Trencavel family and later became an important defensive position. The chateau has been heavily restored and now houses a museum displaying artifacts found in the Cité and its surrounding district.
name: Château et remparts de la cité de Carcassonne
address: 1 Rue Viollet le Duc, 11000 Carcassonne, France

excerpt: Villemoustaussou is a commune in the Aude department in southern France. Wikipedia.
name: Villemoustaussou

excerpt: Castlelike entrance gate though massive stone walls of the medieval fortress city.
detail_description: Porte Narbonnaise is a castle-like entrance gate that leads through massive stone walls into the medieval fortress city of Carcassonne in the south of France. It is one of the largest and most spectacular fortresses globally, making it a must-visit for castle and medieval history enthusiasts. The gate serves as a portal to another world, evoking the rich history of the Cathars and the crusade against them in the Middle Ages.
name: Porte Narbonnaise

detail_description: Carcassonne is a charming and compact city in France, with a well-connected train station that allows for easy exploration of the area. The Gare de Carcassonne connects to major cities and is conveniently located near the historic Place Carnot. In addition to regional services, it serves as a stop for trains traveling from Bordeaux to Marseille. The medieval Cite Medievale within the city offers a magical experience with its stunning surroundings and great views from the ramparts.
name: Carcassonne
address: 1 Av. du Maréchal Joffre, 11000 Carcassonne, France

detail_description: Cocoa & Grapes offers a half-day walking tour in Carcassonne, combining historical exploration with tastings of handmade chocolates and local wines. The tour provides an opportunity to learn about the city's history while enjoying wine and chocolate pairings. Carcassonne is situated in a prominent wine region, making wine tasting a popular activity. Participants can visit vineyards and wineries to experience the area's renowned wines.
name: Cocoa & Grapes - Chocolate & Wine Tasting Walking Tour - THE Food Tour To Do

detail_description: When exploring the citadel, your journey begins with a stroll across the Pont Vieux, also known as the Old Bridge. This historic 210-meter bridge dates back to the 14th century and spans the River Aude, serving as the primary access point to the fortified city in ancient times. As you traverse this iconic structure, you'll be treated to breathtaking views of the citadel, making it an essential part of your visit.
name: Pont Vieux

detail_description: When visiting Aude, wine enthusiasts will find themselves in the midst of a plethora of options such as Fitou, Corbieres, Minervois, Limoux, Cabardes and Malepere. With so many choices available, it can be overwhelming to decide where to begin. Having a car provides the freedom to embark on a personalized wine tour and explore these renowned regions at your own pace.
name: Minervois Services

excerpt: Museum featuring furniture, books & other artifacts used in French schools from 1880 to 1960.
detail_description: Step back in time and immerse yourself in the history of French education at the Musée de l'Ecole. This unique museum offers a glimpse into the school experience from 1880 to 1960, showcasing furniture, books, and various artifacts used during that period. As you wander through its five galleries, you'll encounter old desks, educational materials like cardboard posters and projectors, and even an indoor playground complete with hopscotch in the courtyard.
name: Musée de l'Ecole

excerpt: Imposing Catholic cathedral dating to the 13th century, with fortresslike Gothic architecture.
detail_description: Saint Michael of Carcassonne is a striking 13th-century Catholic cathedral with fortress-like Gothic architecture. The cathedral boasts stunning stained glass, captivating lighting, and intriguing chapels steeped in ancient history. It's recommended to visit early to avoid crowds and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. While some areas may be under maintenance, the overall experience is still impressive.
name: Saint Michael of Carcassonne

excerpt: Tours are available at this museum dedicated to surrealist poet Joë Bousquet in his former home.
detail_description: Maison des mémoires - Maison Joë Bousquet is a museum located in the former home of surrealist poet Joë Bousquet, offering guided tours and free entry. The museum features a permanent exhibition showcasing the life and works of the poet, including his preserved room with personal belongings and an extensive collection of documents, photos, and texts providing valuable biographical insights. Visitors can also explore temporary exhibitions on various topics related to writers.
name: Maison des mémoires - Maison Joë Bousquet

detail_description: Théâtre Jean-Deschamps is an open-air theater located in the medieval city. It was constructed at the beginning of the 20th century and is specifically designed for tragedies, operas, and lyric dramas. Every July, a grand festival takes place to honor the theater, featuring concerts and various performances. Visitors have praised its suitability for concerts, with some mentioning specific events like Robert Plant's performance and Tom Jones' concert.
name: Théâtre Jean-Deschamps

detail_description: Le Bar à Vins de la Cité is a charming and longstanding establishment that has been serving quality food and wines for over 20 years. Nestled in the heart of the medieval town, it offers a serene escape from the bustling city. This hidden gem is perfect for a leisurely lunch or an evening of delicious cocktails and fine French wines. The menu features a variety of tapas, complemented by an impressive selection of beers and wines that can be enjoyed in the shaded courtyard.
name: Le Bar à Vins de la Cité

detail_description: Maison du Cassoulet, located within walking distance of Hotel du Chateau, is a must-visit for those craving authentic French cuisine. The house specialty is the celebrated regional stew Cassoulet, a savory combination of meat, pork, and white beans served in traditional earthenware pots alongside homemade bread and local wine. This renowned dish has historical significance dating back to the Hundred Years War and was brought to Carcassonne by famous chef Prosper Montagne in the 1920s.
name: Maison du Cassoulet
address: 6 Rue du Grand Puits, 11000 Carcassonne, France

detail_description: Le-Bis-Troquet is a charming restaurant located in the heart of Carcassonne, offering a peaceful retreat from the bustling town. The menu features a unique twist with a focus on tartines, providing an affordable dining experience that has garnered overwhelmingly positive reviews from both French and English patrons. The owners are dedicated to delivering consistently delicious meals, with carefully selected local wines complementing the seasonal curated food. Guests can expect friendly service and an array of different dishes that exceed expectations.
name: Le-Bis-Troquet

excerpt: Part of the preserved medieval walled city, this iconic gate overlooks the river.
detail_description: Porte de l'Aude is a historic gate that forms part of the medieval walled city of Carcassonne. It overlooks the river Aude and has a rich history, having been partially destroyed in 1816 to make way for the Saint Gimer church. The gate has also served as a filming location for various period films. Visitors can explore the surrounding area, which features shops and dining options.
name: Porte d’Aude
address: 30 Côte de la Cité, 11000 Carcassonne, France

detail_description: A l'ombre des remparts is a charming destination located in the upper town of Carcassonne, offering a close-up view of the immense fortress. The cobblestone streets lead to various bars, restaurants, and shops. The apartments are beautifully decorated and practical, with exceptional views of the city ramparts. Additionally, they offer free private parking and are pet-friendly. Another cozy apartment provides easy access to both the castle and the city center via a picturesque pedestrian bridge.
name: A l'ombre des remparts

detail_description: Chateau de Pennautier is a stunning 17th-century estate and one of the six vineyards owned by the de Lorgerils family. The property features La Table, a restaurant offering daily menus paired with a variety of AOC wines, including the elegant local Cabardes. Situated just four miles from Carcassonne, the chateau boasts breathtaking architecture and award-winning gardens that are perfect for leisurely strolls or picnics.
name: Chateau de Pennautier

detail_description: The Torture Museum, nestled within the historic walls of Carcassonne, offers a chilling glimpse into Europe's medieval past. While it may not be suitable for everyone—especially those with a weak stomach—this museum provides an educational experience about the grim realities of torture methods and instruments used during that era. Visitors can delve into the harrowing history of the Cathars, a Christian sect that faced severe persecution from the Catholic Church between the 12th and 14th centuries.
name: Torture Museum
address: 5 Rue du Grand Puits, 11000 Carcassonne, France

excerpt: Simple rooms with flat-screens in a casual B&B offering a guest lounge & views of the walled city.
detail_description: La Demeure De La Cite is a bed and breakfast that features flat-screens in the guest lounge as well as views of the walled city.
name: La Demeure De La Cite

detail_description: If you're looking for an unforgettable night out in Carcassonne, look no further than The Night Café. With the charming Henry behind the bar, your experience is sure to be fantastic. I discovered a delightful drink called the cabanel mandarin that quickly became a favorite of mine. The atmosphere is electric with great music and extended hours, making it the ultimate spot for nightlife enthusiasts. While it can get quite crowded, that's all part of the fun!
name: The Night Café

detail_description: Aux Croissants des Lices is a charming bakery and cafe in Carcassonne, known for its delicious pastries and friendly staff. Visitors rave about the almond croissants, fresh bread, cream cakes, and sandwiches. The accommodating and helpful nature of the staff has left a lasting impression on many customers. The atmosphere is described as pleasant and the prices are reasonable. Whether it's for breakfast or lunch, this spot seems to be a favorite among those visiting Carcassonne.
name: Aux Croissants des Lices

detail_description: Rue Trivalle is a charming street located just off Rue Barbacane. It is home to three delightful dining establishments, making it a great spot for food enthusiasts. However, visitors should note that these eateries may be closed at certain times, so it's best to check their schedules in advance.
name: Rue Trivalle

excerpt: Cazilhac is a commune in the Aude department in southern France. Wikipedia.
name: Cazilhac

excerpt:
Caux-et-Sauzens is a commune in the Aude department in southern France.
Located 8 kilometres west of Carcassonne between the Montagne Noire and Malepère, at the crossroads of the old Roman roads to Toulouse and from Foix towards Ariège and Spain. Wikipedia.
name: Caux-et-Sauzens

excerpt: Pennautier is a commune in the Aude department in southern France. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Pennautier, a charming commune in southern France, is located near Carcassonne City and is served by the nearby Carcassonne Airport. This airport sees a high volume of tourists annually due to its close proximity to the stunning medieval city of Carcassonne.
name: Pennautier

detail_description: A group of six people visited O'Vineyards for a four-hour Wine & Dine Celebration evening. They had previously dined at the vineyard many years ago and wanted to revisit. After enjoying a couple of welcome glasses of wine, their host Joe took them on an entertaining tour of the vineyards and winery, where they sampled wines from tanks and barrels. Throughout the evening, Joe poured his wines to complement each course of the sublime food served by Liz.
name: O'Vineyards Wine Tour. Winery Visits.
address: 885 Av. de la Montagne Noire, 11620 Villemoustaussou, France

excerpt: Australian-themed wildlife park with native animals, panning for gold & boomerang lessons.
detail_description: LE PARC AUSTRALIEN parc animalier intéractif offers a unique experience with Australian wildlife and culture. Visitors can enjoy guided tours with engaging explanations about the animals, as well as interactive experiences such as feeding kangaroos, ostriches, and parrots. The park also provides opportunities to learn about traditional music instruments like the didgeridoo and offers activities like panning for gold and boomerang lessons.
name: Le Parc AUSTRALIEN - Parc animalier intéractif
address: Direction Montlegun/Lac de la Cavayère, Chem. des Bartavelles, 11000 Carcassonne, France

detail_description: The Abbaye de Caunes-Minervois is a beautiful and historically rich abbey with a fascinating past. The staff is known for being warm and accommodating, making visitors feel welcome. Although no longer home to resident priests, the abbey still holds special occasions for the local townspeople. Its Roman architecture is one of its most interesting features, and the original foundation dating back 1,200 years can be seen underneath the abbey.
name: Abbaye de Caunes-Minervois

detail_description: Église Saint-Vincent de Carcassonne is often mistaken for the town's cathedral due to its size and grandeur. The church features a 54-meter tall bell tower dating back to the 14th century, along with beautiful stained glass, a gilded ornamented organ, and restored gargoyle features adorning the outside of the nave. Visitors can climb a significant number of steps to reach the top of the tower, where they are rewarded with a panoramic view.
name: Église Saint-Vincent de Carcassonne
address: 79 Rue du Dr Albert Tomey, 11000 Carcassonne, France

detail_description: When in Carcassonne, a visit to the Centre Culturel de la Mémoire Combattante is a must. This small museum near the medieval city walls showcases an impressive collection of artifacts, old military uniforms, photos, and memorabilia focusing on French military history. The exhibition also includes a section dedicated to the local area during World War II. Visitors can enjoy a tour guided by friendly staff who are passionate about sharing their knowledge of military history.
name: Centre Culturel de la Mémoire Combattante

detail_description: La Fontaine de Neptune is a large 17th-century fountain located in the central square of Carcassonne. The area around it is car-free and filled with terraces, second-hand book stalls, and active shops. It's a popular spot for locals and tourists alike, especially on sunny days when children can be seen playing in the water. The square also features numerous bars and restaurants offering a variety of cuisines. Visitors can enjoy fresh fruit presses while taking in the lively atmosphere.
name: La Fontaine de Neptune

detail_description: Château Auzias Paretlongue offers a diverse selection of high-quality wines, showcasing the unique influences of both the Mediterranean and Atlantic climates on their grape varieties. The winery's "Twins" collection provides an intriguing comparison between these two terroirs. Despite being a lesser-known producer in the UK compared to larger Cabardes wineries, Château Auzias Paretlongue is deserving of support for their exceptional wines.
name: Château Auzias Paretlongue

detail_description: Chapelle Notre-Dame du Cros is a magnificent 9th-century chapel surrounded by splendid surroundings. The area offers great hiking opportunities, with challenging walks in the gorges and rock climbing. Despite the current closure for renovation, the village itself is charming, featuring a quiet park ideal for picnics. Visitors can also explore troglodyte statues and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere of this special place, which becomes even more beautiful as the flora changes colors and shadows lengthen.
name: Chapelle Notre-Dame du Cros
